params.question: As well as symbol reservation and origination, what else can be done with security tokens?
What is the ticker registration on Polymesh for?

answers.text: The ticker will continuously update the token value.
The ticker forwards on-chain events.
A ticker will keep track of the token supply.
Registering a ticker ensures no other user can issue an asset with that ticker whilst the registration is valid.

params.question: Which elements determine ownership of a token's underlying asset?

answers.text: The sum of balances of an individual investor's account(s) of said asset.
The total supply of tokens representing ownership of said asset.
Custody. Whoever has control of the token is its de facto owner.
The network owns everything.

params.question: Why does Token Studio ask for your name although it is clearly displayed in your wallet?

answers.text: Token Studio can see the account but cannot know the name stored in the wallet or the information that was provided to the customer due diligence service provider.
Token Studio asks for an additional authentication for security reasons.
You can and should use a pseudonym when using Token Studio.
Token Studio only stores this information in memory.

params.question: Thinking of secondary keys: Alice, as an ACME representative, needs a key for signing. How could ACME go about it?

answers.text: ACME can create a key for this purpose and give it to Alice.
Only Alice can assign and sign a key.
Alice can create a key and have it signed by ACME.
ACME can create a key and give the public portion to ACME. ACME can assign signing authority and permissions to this key.

params.question: Which of the following statements are true?

answers.text: Accounts can delegate authority to other users using secondary keys.
Users can assign keys that belong to other users to their own account, but only if the owners of those keys (who exclusively hold the private keys) consent to the assignment.
